title: 110_s1944
content: The Act may be cited as the "Justice for Victims of State Sponsored Terrorism Act" and includes a terrorism exception to immunity. The "Justice for Victims of State Sponsored Terrorism Act" includes a terrorism exception to the jurisdictional immunity of a foreign state, allowing courts in the United States to hear cases seeking money damages for personal injury or death caused by acts such as torture, extrajudicial killing, aircraft sabotage, hostage taking, or providing material support for such acts by officials, employees, or agents of the foreign state. The court shall hear a claim under this section if the foreign state was designated as a state sponsor of terrorism at the time the act occurred and the claimant or victim was a national of the United States. The court will hear a claim under this section if the foreign state was designated as a state sponsor of terrorism at the time the act occurred and the claimant or victim was a national of the United States. The definition for this section includes individuals who are members of the Armed Forces of the United States, employees of the government or its contractors, and those who have given the foreign state a chance to arbitrate the claim. The section defines terms like 'torture', 'extrajudicial killing', 'hostage taking', and 'aircraft sabotage'. An action must be brought within 10 years of April 24, 1996, or within 10 years of the cause of action arising. A private right of action is allowed under this section. A private cause of action may be brought against a foreign state designated under the Export Administration Act of 1979 for personal injury or death caused by acts of that foreign state or its officials, employees, or agents. The United States may have jurisdiction for money damages, including economic damages, solatium, pain, suffering, and punitive damages for certain acts. A foreign state can be held vicariously liable for its officials, employees, or agents. Additional damages for property loss, third party liability, and insurance claims can also be pursued. Special masters may be appointed by US courts to hear damage claims under this section. Transfer funds from the Victims Crime Act to the US District Court for cases brought under section 1605(a)(7) to appoint Special Masters. Compensation for Special Masters is considered court costs. Appeals can only be made for orders conclusively ending litigation. Property disposition in actions filed in US district courts under this section is specified. The filing of a notice of pending action in a district court establishes a lien on property titled in the name of defendants or entities controlled by them. The notice must list all defendants and controlled entities. The filing of a notice of pending action in a district court establishes a lien on property titled in the name of defendants or entities controlled by them, enforceable as provided in chapter 111 of this title. Amendment to Chapter Analysis for chapter 97 of title 28, United States Code includes inserting a new item after section 1605. The text introduces a terrorism exception to the jurisdictional immunity of a foreign state. Conforming amendments are also mentioned. The text introduces an amendment to Section 1610 of title 28, United States Code, allowing for the execution of judgments against the property of a foreign state or its entities, regardless of economic control or government involvement. The amendment to Section 1610 of title 28, United States Code, allows for the execution of judgments against the property of a foreign state or its entities, irrespective of government involvement or economic control. This includes cases where the foreign state is the sole beneficiary of the property or where establishing the property as a separate entity would benefit the foreign state in U.S. courts. The United States sovereign immunity does not apply to such properties regulated by the U.S. government under certain acts. The Victims of Crime Act is amended to change the date for investigations, and Section 1605 of title 28, United States Code, is amended by removing certain subsections. SEC. 4. APPLICATION TO PENDING CASES. The amendments made by this Act apply to claims under section 1605A or 1605(g) of title 28, United States Code. Any judgment or action under section 1605(a)(7) or section 101(c) of Public Law 104-208 affected by these provisions can be refiled under section 1605A(d) of title 28, United States Code. The Act allows for claims under section 1605A or 1605(g) of title 28, United States Code to be refiled within 60 days of enactment, waiving certain defenses like res judicata and limitation periods.
